utterances: But now no banquets are being served.
The restaurant is closed.
There's simply no business after the earthquake.
All tours to Chengdu have been cancelled.
This restaurant is built around a beautiful courtyard garden.
There's a pagoda and bamboo plants and a couple dogs running around and a fishpond, goldfish.
Everything look fine there.
It's still lovely.
But this restaurant is closed, closed ever since the earthquake and closed for - how long do you think this restaurant will stay closed?
(Chinese spoken)
He doesn't know.
He'll just have to see how things go.
(Chinese spoken)
They're still being affected by this panic, and their workers are still very unsettled, and they've brought their families here to avoid further aftershocks.
The workers have been sleeping on chairs right by the front door.
Yu Bo has emergency cartons of noodles, crackers and water bottles stacked up there, too.
(Chinese spoken)
He said the only thing he can do is to lay out these foods and drinks by the door.
And if there is a further - another earthquake, they can just grab these things and be out the door quickly, and they'll be able to keep everybody together.
As he heads back through the restaurant courtyard, Yu Bo stops to pinch the cheek of a small boy who's come to stay at the restaurant with his mother, one of the workers here.
They'll stay here for who knows how long - until they feel safe to go home.
(Soundbite of music)
You're listening to ALL THINGS CONSIDERED from NPR News.
From NPR News, this is ALL THINGS CONSIDERED.
I'm Melissa Block.
And I'm Robert Siegel.

Hurricane Wilma moved into southwest Florida at dawn today as a Category 3 storm with 125-mile-per-hour winds that took off roofs, damaged homes, downed power lines and brought flooding as far south as Key West.
The same storm that walloped Mexico's Yucatan Peninsula with even stronger winds over the weekend kept up some strength as it crossed Florida into the Miami-Ft.
Lauderdale area.
Off the Florida coast, Cuba also took a beating.
There was flooding in Havana.
We have four reports from both coasts of Florida and from Mexico, where residents are still staggering from Wilma's destruction.
First, NPR's Luke Burbank is in Everglades City, close to where Wilma hit the US Gulf Coast.
Ricky Smith was born and raised in the tiny fishing town of Everglades City, Florida; population, 600.
So after 47 years and almost as many storms, he figured he'd ride Wilma out, no problem.
First part of the storm wasn't too bad; probably hundred-mile-an-hour winds.
When the last part came through, after the eye went over, it was devastating at times--worst I've seen.
Smith's house lost its siding and suffered water damage.
But, he says, he was one of the lucky ones.
Some of my friends and family didn't fare so well: a lot of roof damage, some complete roofs; some, water's all the way up in their houses, things like that.
But it could be worse.
It's not Katrina, so thank God for what we got.
Over the weekend it became pretty clear that Wilma would hit somewhere on the southwestern tip of Florida, but no one knew exactly how powerful it would be.
Some models said it would be a 1; some, a 2.
It ended up being a 3.
And Paul Wilson, who runs the local emergency response, says it felt stronger than that to him.
The back side of the storm was a strong 3, wanting to push Category 4-type water into us.
And it produced a lot of tornadoes.
One of which hit the emergency staging center some 15 miles away.
That further complicated things for Wilson and his men.
And when they did finally make it down the road to see what happened to the town, where many of them also live, it wasn't pretty.
A storm surge of water had swamped the entire area.
We have four feet of water, we have a lot of downed power lines, we have leaning power poles, we have a lot of trees down.
We have some roof peeling.
But to really get a sense for just how waterlogged Everglades City is, you have to see it for yourself.
(Soundbite of truck)
We're driving up Collier Street on the back of an emergency management truck, although you can't see Collier Street.
It's under about a foot of water.
Looking around Everglades City, you can tell this is a town that's had its share of floodings.
Many of the homes are built up on stilts, clearly people who got the message years ago that this is a flood-prone area.

For the people who didn't heed the warning and for those whose homes are on the ground level--nothing catastrophic, but it's enough that it'll be a long time before Everglades City looks like it did yesterday.
Luke Burbank, NPR News, Everglades City, Florida.
Congress is finishing up a two-week recess.

Yes, hard to believe Congress actually has been in recess given all the activity on Capitol Hill, including today, when Marie Yovanovitch testified before the House committees running the impeachment inquiry.
Marie Yovanovitch was U.S.
ambassador to Ukraine until she was ousted in May.
And it wasn't clear today until the last minute if she would indeed show up.
The State Department had told her not to testify.
But the committee subpoenaed her, and she complied.

So the Yovanovitch testimony is just one of such a deluge of developments that we wanted to hit pause and invite two of our best sourced reporters tracking this story to come share their takeaways from a crazy week.
Congressional correspondent Susan Davis joins us from Capitol Hill.
Hi there, Sue.
Hi there.
And justice correspondent Ryan Lucas is here in the studio.
Welcome to you.
Thank you.
(Singing) You've been packing your bags for the tenth time.
You've been up on the roof again.
So you're biding your time, but it's all right.
They're coming any week now...
Soltis says amborella is a bit of a puzzle in the flowering plant world.
Unlike the other early flowering plants, it doesn't have any direct descendants, sort of like the platypus, a relative of all mammals but the ancestor of none.
But that also makes it useful to plant geneticists.
It provides a reference point for orienting all of the other changes that have occurred within the flowering plants.

The flowering plants may be more important to gardeners and farmers with their gaudy leaves and tasty fruit, but Jody Banks says she intends to keep her research focused on the more pedestrian Selaginella.
It's a survivor.
It's been around hundreds of millions of years.
And who knows, if there's a next mass extinction, it may be what's left.
Joe Palca, NPR News, Washington.
NPR's business news starts with South Korea backtracking on beef.
(Soundbite of music)
Just a week ago, South Korea's president said that country would resume full imports of American beef.
Now he says he won't allow in beef from older cattle, those more than 30 months old.
The backpedaling came after widespread public protest.
South Korea used to be the third largest overseas market for American beef.
Then a case of mad cow disease in Washington State several years ago prompted Seoul to impose a ban.
As the two countries hammered out a deal to resume imports, South Korean Internet and TV reports fueled fears of mad cow disease.
Underlying the beef issue is Koreans' frustration with their current president, but the decision to postpone U.S.
beef imports could threaten a broader free trade deal between Seoul and Washington.
This is ALL THINGS CONSIDERED from NPR News.
I'm Guy Raz.
A nuclear energy renaissance could be just around the corner here in the U.S.
with more money and more political support than at any other time in the past three decades.
That story is coming up in a moment.
But first, an update from Chile.
The sounds of water cannons spraying people in the earthquake-stricken city of Concepcion.
Police tried to keep some residents from looting.
But one woman said given the desperate circumstances, there is no other option.
(Speaking foreign language).
At least 700 people were killed and millions temporarily displaced after that 8.8 magnitude earthquake.
Reporter Annie Murphy is on the road, heading to Concepcion, the city closest to the epicenter.
Right now, she's in the town of Renaico just south of Concepcion, and Annie, describe what the town looks like at the moment where you are.
